metadata.title: CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORKS ON NONUNIFORM GEOMETRICAL SIGNALS USING EUCLIDEAN
metadata.author: SPECTRAL TRANSFORMATION
metadata.abstract: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) have been successful in processing data signals that are uniformly sampled in the spatial domain (e.g., images). However, most data signals do not natively exist on a grid, and in the process of being sampled onto a uniform physical grid suffer significant aliasing error and information loss. Moreover, signals can exist in different topological structures as, for example, points, lines, surfaces and volumes. It has been challenging to analyze signals with mixed topologies (for example, point cloud with surface mesh). To this end, we develop mathematical formulations for Non-Uniform Fourier Transforms (NUFT) to directly, and optimally, sample nonuniform data signals of different topologies defined on a simplex mesh into the spectral domain with no spatial sampling error. The spectral transform is performed in the Euclidean space, which removes the translation ambiguity from works on the graph spectrum. Our representation has four distinct advantages: (1) the process causes no spatial sampling error during the initial sampling, (2) the generality of this approach provides a unified framework for using CNNs to analyze signals of mixed topologies, (3) it allows us to leverage state-of-the-art backbone CNN architectures for effective learning without having to design a particular architecture for a particular data structure in an ad-hoc fashion, and (4) the representation allows weighted meshes where each element has a different weight (i.e., texture) indicating local properties. We achieve results on par with the state-of-the-art for the 3D shape retrieval task, and a new state-of-the-art for the point cloud to surface reconstruction task.

highlights: We present a unifying and novel geometry representation for utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) on geometries represented on weighted simplex meshes which preserve maximal shape information based on the Fourier transformation
Most methods that leverage Convolutional Neural Networks for shape learning preprocess these shapes into uniform-grid based 2D images or 3D images)

For the shape retrieval task, most state-of-the-art methods are based on multi-view representation that utilize a 2D Convolutional Neural Networks pretrained on additional 2D datasets such as ImageNet

We present a general representation for multidimensional signals defined on simplicial complexes that is versatile across geometrical deep learning tasks and maximizes the preservation of shape information

We offer an alternative representation for performing Convolutional Neural Networks based learning on geometrical signals that shows great potential in various 3D tasks, especially tasks involving mixed-topology signals
key_statements: We present a unifying and novel geometry representation for utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) on geometries represented on weighted simplex meshes which preserve maximal shape information based on the Fourier transformation
Most methods that leverage Convolutional Neural Networks for shape learning preprocess these shapes into uniform-grid based 2D images or 3D images)

We evaluate the effectiveness of our shape representation for deep learning tasks with three experiments: a controlled MNIST toy example, the 3D shape retrieval task, and a more challenging 3D point cloud to surface reconstruction task
We empirically show that our representation preserves maximal shape information compared to commonly used binary voxel and Signed Distance Function representations. (Sec. 4.1)

We show that deep learning models using Convolutional Neural Networks in conjunction with our shape representation achieves state-of-the-art performance across a range of shape-learning tasks including shape retrieval (Sec. 4.2) and point to surface reconstruction (Sec. 4.3)

For the shape retrieval task, most state-of-the-art methods are based on multi-view representation that utilize a 2D Convolutional Neural Networks pretrained on additional 2D datasets such as ImageNet

We present a general representation for multidimensional signals defined on simplicial complexes that is versatile across geometrical deep learning tasks and maximizes the preservation of shape information
We develop a set of mathematical formulations and algorithmic tools to perform the transformations efficiently

We offer an alternative representation for performing Convolutional Neural Networks based learning on geometrical signals that shows great potential in various 3D tasks, especially tasks involving mixed-topology signals
summary: We present a unifying and novel geometry representation for utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) on geometries represented on weighted simplex meshes which preserve maximal shape information based on the Fourier transformation.

The signal is defined on a simplex mesh, it is treated as a signal in the Euclidean space instead of on a graph, differentiating our framework from graph-based spectral learning techniques which have significant difficulties generalizing across topologies and unable to utilize state-of-the-art Cartesian CNNs. We evaluate the effectiveness of our shape representation for deep learning tasks with three experiments: a controlled MNIST toy example, the 3D shape retrieval task, and a more challenging 3D point cloud to surface reconstruction task.
We develop mathematical formulations for performing Fourier Transforms of signals defined on a simplex mesh, which generalizes and extends to all geometries in all dimensions.
We are the first to provide a simple general expression for a j-simplex mesh, an algorithm to perform the transformation, and illustrations of their applicability to deep learning problems.
Fnj (k) = ij γnj t=1 e−iσt j+1 l=1,l=t the final general expression for computing the Fourier transform of a signal defined on a weighted simplex mesh is: N
Auxiliary Node Method: Equation (3) provides a mean of computing the Fourier transform of a simplex with uniform signal density.
The auxiliary node method performs Fourier transform over the the signed content bounded by an auxilliary node and each (j − 1)-simplex on the boundary mesh.
To compute the Fourier transform of uniform signals in j-polytopes represented by its watertight (j − 1)-simplex mesh using the auxiliary node method, we modify Equation (3): Nn

We compare the retrieval performance of our model utilizing the NUFT-surface (NUFT-S) and NUFT-volume (NUFT-V) at various resolutions against state-of-the-art shape retrieval algorithms to illustrate its potential in a range of 3D learning problems.

For the shape retrieval task, most state-of-the-art methods are based on multi-view representation that utilize a 2D CNN pretrained on additional 2D datasets such as ImageNet. We have achieved results on par with, though not better than, state-of-the-art pretrained 2D models.

We present a general representation for multidimensional signals defined on simplicial complexes that is versatile across geometrical deep learning tasks and maximizes the preservation of shape information.

We illustrate the effectiveness of the NUFT representation with a well-controlled example (MNIST polygon), a classic 3D task and a difficult and mostly unexplored task by deep learning, achieving new state-of-the-art performance in the last task.
We offer an alternative representation for performing CNN based learning on geometrical signals that shows great potential in various 3D tasks, especially tasks involving mixed-topology signals
headline: We develop mathematical formulations for Non-Uniform Fourier Transforms to directly, and optimally, sample nonuniform data signals of different topologies defined on a simplex mesh into the spectral domain with no spatial sampling error
